nodes.bodyText: How about using NullableTime for the OAS "time" type instead of plain "string" type? At least specifically for go-experimental, because this would be a breaking change for "go". Golang has the time.Time.Truncate() function, which could help to perform arithmetic with dates.

It's not very clear where in the pom.xml these two lines should be added.
Should we add a "go-experimental" profile in the top-level pom.xml? Similar to https://github.com/OpenAPITools/openapi-generator/blob/master/pom.xml#L911?
It would be good to add XML comments to explain the purpose of the profiles in the top-level pom.xml file. Specifically, there are 4 profiles that use a different JDK. Why? I'd like to add an XML comment to explain. Is it done because some samples require a specific version of the JDK? Or because someone wanted to make sure the sample can compile against multiple JDK versions? Or because whoever added the sample found a spot where to add the sample, without thinking about which JDK is needed?


https://github.com/OpenAPITools/openapi-generator/blob/master/pom.xml#L1031
https://github.com/OpenAPITools/openapi-generator/blob/master/pom.xml#L1086
https://github.com/OpenAPITools/openapi-generator/blob/master/pom.xml#L1178
https://github.com/OpenAPITools/openapi-generator/blob/master/pom.xml#L1240

Is it done because some samples require a specific version of the JDK?

Yes

Why not invoke the following code in go-experimental processOpts() instead of modifying the dataType here? What is the reason for changing the type in postProcessModels()?
typeMapping.put("DateTime", "NullableTime");
Agreed with using typeMapping to directly map the type instead of using the code above.

So interestingly, adding typeMapping.put("DateTime", "NullableTime") does not produce the same output for the samples. I wonder if that was done on purpose. When the dataType is set in postProcessModels(), it does not have the same effect as when typeMapping is invoked in processOpts(). Is that done on purpose?
We only want to represent the DateTime object as NullableTime if it's marked as nullable in the spec. I don't think we should use it in all cases.
Yeah, I agree this PR is ok as-is, let's keep more changes for followup PRs.

We only want to represent the DateTime object as NullableTime if it's marked as nullable in the spec. I don't think we should use it in all cases.

Thanks for the explanation. I have added code comments to explain.

Yeah, I agree this PR is ok as-is, let's keep more changes for followup PRs.

Thanks. Can you approve the PR then? Approving in the text does not help much. BTW, for some reason I am unable to add you as a reviewer.
Approved. Sorry, I keep forgetting doing the official review.
I've added error checking, but it does not seem a good idea to depend on the Python module.
Yup, better to copy the file (png) to the root directory of the go experimental petstore client.
Should I copy all of the existing unit test files from samples/client/petstore/go-experimental?
done, running the unit tests to verify.
